Award.AwardTitle: Examining Coaching in Elementary (K-8) Mathematics Classrooms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
DRL: DR K-12
PI: Yopp

Abstract

The project Examining Coaching in Elementary Mathematics Classrooms, led by faculty of Montana State University and professional staff of RMC Research Corporation, is conducting correlational and experimental studies of elementary mathematics coaching to see how knowledge about coaching strategy and about mathematics content influences the ability of coaches to improve teachers' knowledge, attitudes, and classroom practices.

The project explores the hypothesis that the effectiveness of a mathematics classroom coach in changing teacher practice, attitudes, and beliefs is positively correlated with his/her knowledge about coaching strategies and about mathematics content. To test this hypothesis, this project is addressing two core research questions:

1. To what extent does a coach's depth of knowledge in two primary domains (coaching knowledge and mathematics content knowledge) influence coaching effectiveness?

2. To what extent does professional development targeting those two knowledge domains improve coaching effectiveness?

The first research question is being addressed by a non-experimental correlational study of knowledge for coaching and change in teacher practice as a result of coaching. The second question is being studied by an experimental causal cross-over design measuring the effects of professional development provided to increase the knowledge of coaches. The designs address effects of coaching on teachers' classroom instruction, an critical link in the connection between coaching and improved student learning.

The correlational data is analyzed by structural equation modeling. The experimental data is analyzed by hierarchical linear modeling, nesting teachers within coaches. Approximately 60 coaches are randomly assigned to treatment and control groups, and each coach works with 3 teachers. The various facets of coach and teacher knowledge and practice are measured by a variety of existing and previously validated instruments.

Results of the study will provide valuable evidence to schools considering use of mathematics coaches as a strategy for improving results of elementary mathematics instruction.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Examining Mathematics Coaching (EMC) Project was funded by the NSF DRK-12 program. It was a research study that examined the effects of variations in a coach’s knowledge for coaching on a diverse population of elementary-grades teachers, focusing on the classroom-supporter role of a coach. We investigated coaches’ mathematics knowledge and coaching knowledge and the effects of those on teachers’ mathematics knowledge, classroom practice, and attitudes. The study used both an experimental and nonexperimental phase, and it included qualitative data collection and analysis where appropriate. At the heart of our study were practical questions:

  • What must a coach know about mathematical content and how to coach teachers to be an effective coach?
  • Can professional development for coaches in either of these areas improve a coach’s effectiveness?

Intellectual Merit. Our results support mathematics classroom coaching as a school-based strategy for influencing teacher practice, knowledge, and attitudes. We found that as coaches’ assessments of their coaching skills increased, so did teachers’ mathematics knowledge, attitudes, and use of standards-based practices. We found that improvements over time in coaches’ alignment with the recommendations of predominant coaching texts were related to increases in teachers’ mathematics knowledge for teaching. We did not find that these improvements were related to changes in teachers’ attitudes or classroom practice. We found no evidence that improvements in coaches’ mathematics knowledge for teaching were related to increases in any teacher measures.

We found evidence that professional development about how to coach teachers had direct effects on coaches’ assessments of their coaching skills. We found no evidence that professional development about mathematics had direct effects on coaches’ mathematics knowledge for teaching.

Broader Impact. Over the course of the project we prepared almost 60 coaches who worked with nearly 250 teachers in the project and many more teachers overall. The settings for the study were diverse, including rural, urban, and suburban school districts, along with districts whose student populations are predominantly Native American. The diverse nature of the school districts whose coaches participated in our study, combined with the way that our project studied mathematics coaches in the varied contexts in which coaching is being enacted in those school districts, provides evidence that the results from this study are useful in understanding coaching in varied settings. The enduring products that result from this project are a coaching model; professional development for coaches on coaching knowledge; and instruments and measures that can be used for monitoring coaching sessions, reflecting on the effectiveness of participants’ coaching relationships and structure, and measuring coaches’ self-assessment of their coaching skills and knowledge of coaching recommendations.

Modified by: Elizabeth A Burroughs
